author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Chase Utley two-game ban appeal hearing postponed
text:
Howard Simmons/New York Daily News Chase Utley takes out Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada, breaking his leg. Chase Utley is a distant memory for the Mets as they march into Chicago up 2-0 on the Cubs in the NLCS.
But while the Dodgers are out of the playoffs, thanks to the Mets' Game 5 NLDS clinching win last week, Utley still has the matter of his appeal of the two-game ban he received for his takeout slide of Ruben Tejada in Game 2 of the divisional series that was played at Dodger Stadium.
Although the hearing was scheduled for Monday in New York, the Daily News has learned that Utley's appeal will be heard at a later date. Should the second baseman lose his appeal, he would serve the two-game ban at the start of the 2016 season.
LIVE BLOG: FOLLOW THE METS-CUBS NLCS HERE
Utley barreled into Tejada as the Mets' shortstop took a relay throw from Daniel Murphy with his back to first base. The slide was well away from second base, and Tejada was upended and broke his right fibula as a result. The Dodgers won Game 2 but ultimately lost the series in five games. Utley was lustily booed at Citi Field during pre-game introductions when the series shifted to Flushing.
Joe Torre, Major League Baseball's chief discipline czar, issued the ban for Games 3 and 4 of the NLDS, but Utley appealed, allowing him to be in uniform while the appeals process played out. Utley didn't play in the two games at Citi Field, but was a pinch hitter in the Game 5 Mets' win.
When the hearing does eventually occur, it will be before John McHale Jr., MLB's Executive VP of Administration.
